title: Wednesday, 21th March, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Hey!

A. M. Morning.
BE11:06am

Hello welcome hi there good morning this is Markets Live FTAlphaville's daily thing with etc

Tom Dalgleish hi
Soundbuy Morgen......
Tom Dalgleish evening
Paper Chase Hullo
casapinos ho
OnYourRight Morning all
BE11:07am

Where to start? I guess here, albeit somewhat reluctantly.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Swedish Chef “Material issues” at Moss Bros. I see
Blank canvas good morning all
Swedish Chef ROTR about to start fish puns...
A. M. @BE: doesn't that count as pollution (unless the fish are alive)?
BE11:08am

You won't read a better lead par today, I'll wager. Full story over on Fast: https://www.ft.com...-a34a-7e7563b0b0f4

GBKrona Jacob Rees-Mongrel missed the boat as he couldn't even organise that
Pseudonym They should have had some kind of fish cannon to plaster the Palace of Westminster in herring.
BE11:08am

(@AM: um ............ maybe? I guess?)

A. M. (up north, in Norway, there's a bathtub-sailing competition, where fish-flinging is part of the fun.)
Blank canvas could these fish protesters be fined for polluting the Thames?
11:09 am
BE11:10am

Meanwhile, over in the bit of the media that tries to take things serious, we're still. Shouting. A. Lot. About. Facebook.

BE11:10am

Down 1.7% live, pre market, with a fairly decent 138k traded.

Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous and assorted people
Soundbuy Those Norwegians know how to live it up.......
Plato the Cook They weren't even flying a red ensign. Just not British, dammit!
GBKrona @Blank Canvas - yes - police boat chasing Farage's Brittania as we speak along the Thames https://t.co/R5tXAxbKHI
A. M. @Soundbuy: well, not everybody is lucky enough to engage in cheese-rolling, I suppose.
BE11:11am

And the more we shout, the further it seems we drift away from the point.

pancakes or waffles Axios reporting zuckerberg may speak up within next 24h
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian They forgot to throw off their biggest fish!
Electric Dragon https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IhJQp-q1Y1s
11:11 am
BE11:11am

this is a good tether back, whatever your opinion: https://medium.com...bacle-b69fe692d747

Blank canvas GBKrona: great fun, were it not so serious
Grouchmonkey Morning internet friends and assorted Cambridge Analytica chatbots
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Fishy Farage - the larget red herring you will ever catch!
GBKrona Briall @electric dragon
BE11:12am

Someone who actually knows what they're talking about, explaining what the Graph API was for and how it was allegedly abused.

GBKrona @Blank Canvas - indeed
nichoman i do feel a little bit like media is running with Cambridge analytica's self aggrandizing claims of their own dark powers...ie we can win elections. isn't much of what they do stuff advertisers have been doing for a long time...
h1 MOSS BROS - down down down :D @BE
Miss Piggy Never mind the pollocks, here's Markets Live
Pseudonym Farage always struck me more as a gurnard than a herring.
Mouselet nichoman: I think that individually targetted advertising is meaningfully new
Forester Pressed the "download" button for my FB data yesterday - apparently takes hours to pull the data together. Still waiting 24 hours later but i guess their systems busy!
OnYourRight Salt water fish dumped in fresh water........Animal cruelty?!?!?!
Blank canvas I took part in a scientific survey last night about interactive social media, and the subtext was whether I could trust Facebook. Not difficult to answer that.
BE11:14am

Anyway, we're well past the point that anyone will ever change their mind here so have some links instead.

Mouselet ( I remember journalists going through a black neighbourhood of DC in I think 2004 and seeing that someone had put up 'don't forget to vote on 9 November' signs - note the election was on 2 November )
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Main story here: https://www.ft.com...-22a0-7603348b7f22

Mouselet I think the fish were already dead
BornCynic Morning
Plato the Cook @Blank Canvas: that was more likely a data-gathering exercise
BE11:15am

Sidebar story here: https://www.ft.com...-22a0-7603348b7f22

1 bid at 2 Soph dead cat bounce or more to it ?
Miss Piggy Throwing in dead fish must count as littering.
1 bid at 2 Talking of cats..Softcat...
BE11:16am

Profile of Alex Nix here, ahead of him being played by Colin Firth in the movie: https://www.ft.com...-22a0-7603348b7f22

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Legal angle here: https://www.ft.com...-a34a-7e7563b0b0f4

Blank canvas Plato: I don't have a FB account but the account in the name of my dog who died 8 years ago still gets lots of messages and likes. :)
Mouselet Oh dear Moss Bros. Maybe I can pick up a cheap suit in the bankruptcy sale?
BE11:17am

Academic somehow fails to use the pun "scrapegoat" defence story here: https://www.ft.com...-a34a-7e7563b0b0f4

Manxish @Mouse - I had the exact same thought tbh
Pseudonym I suppose they could have launched shellfish with a clay pigeon launcher..
BE11:17am

Extrapolation theory here: https://www.ft.com...-82e3-332cc1b47827

Mouselet { I managed the classic error of putting the dinner jacket into the local dry cleaner, losing the ticket, and forgetting about it until the next need for a dinner jacket by which time the dry cleaner had disposed of it :( )
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Podcast summary here: https://www.ft.com...-bfe9-3017bb79f884

BE11:17am

Analysis here: https://www.ft.com...-9b4b-bc4b9f08f381

BE11:18am

More analysis here: https://www.ft.com...-b27e-cc62a39d57a0

11:18 am
BE11:18am

More analysis here: https://www.ft.com...-a34a-7e7563b0b0f4

GBKrona @Mouselet - can already buy suits for £40-50 - but they are very much out of fashion! Hoping to pick up some nice shirts though....
A. M. @Mouselet: odd, weren't they doing 'social clothing' before it became a thing?
Mouselet Whilst I respect Bryce deeply, I am not entirely sure that listing eighty-gronk links to the Financial Times itself is the best use of all things
Paper Chase Do you have anything on the Facebook story?
Bonnemort I remember lots of gushing pieces about Obama's brilliant voter analytics team using social media data, "harnessing the power of freindship".
BE11:18am

Leftfield analysis here: http://ftalphavill...reason-to-buy-yen/

BornCynic Main story of the day is that one third of British adults cannot work out what should be the correct change from a shopping trip. Which sort of explains all these misselling scandals...........Take the test:http://www.oecd.org/skills/piaac/
Swedish Chef Here in Stuttgart they have a huge rail project being built to connect city and airport to France and Austria with high speed rail. We are throwing fish. #jokenation indeed.
Miss Piggy #Fish: apparently UK messed up upon entry in 1973.
BE11:19am

Actually, just do this: https://www.ft.com/search?q=facebook

Mouselet our major project to connect London to France was a little while back ...
11:19 am
BE11:19am

The stories are going up faster than I can type.

Bonnemort or friendship. We seem to have gone seamlessly from "it was Russia" to "it was Cambridge Analytica"
undefined
BE11:19am

And to markets? Sure, to markets.

Mouselet It can be both!
h1 MOSS Bros @BE
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Moss Bros mentioned a few times.

Istrain Any grey on big ticket retailers?
Moss Bros Group PLC (MOSB:LSE): Last: 46.00, down 12.6 (-21.50%), High: 47.60, Low: 39.00, Volume: 468.15k
Miss Piggy Oxfam does suits
Pseudonym Sheesh, who cares about facebook anyway you'd have to be off your rocker to put anything that matters on it.
Mouselet Harnessing the power of friendship (IE persuading people to pester their friends to vote) is I think meaningfully different from persuading people-measured-as-influencable not to vote
Mouselet pseudonym: the entire point of this is that the things that don't matter turn out to produce a good psychological profile of you!
Swedish Chef London. HS1 &2 wont connect. After we are all dead Northerners will be lugging suitcases up the Euston Rd. Meanwhile in Germany...
A. M. @Pseudonym: true that may be, but apparently there are enough people who do.
BE11:21am

Retail warning, which is hardly out of the ordinary. Tough trading and difficult time for the traditional business (as in suit hire) versus upstart competitors (as in Primark's tux for £20).

11:21 am
BE11:21am

However! It has a twist.

Mouselet The idea of using Facebook as a news source strikes me as the same level of oddity as using anchovies as a contraceptive
Pseudonym @Mouse Not me, FB knows nothing about me at all.
Mouselet But I suspect you have the privilege of living near your social circle
BE11:22am

So what happened here is that back in 2016, Moss Bros decided it would go own label.

Paper Chase @mouselet Exactly. The things that can be reliably inferred about someone from a large dataset of seemingly trivial connections, likes, comments etc are truly amazing.
Mouselet Facebook is a really good tool for enlarging the water-hole around which the social primates are grooming. It has made dozens of millions of people less isolated.
BE11:22am

Dollar-sterling deprecation meant it seemed a good idea to switch from about 20% own-label stock to about 80%.

Bonnemort I suppose Hillary COULDN'T "just have lost". There has to be a villain.
11:22 am
BE11:23am

Good way to defend gross margin against the costs.

Mouselet "Moss Bros. is an editor for men" !
BE11:23am

Unfortunately, this meant Moss Bros was totally reliant on just two suppliers.

Mouselet { pokes bonnemort with a stick }
Miss Piggy @Bonnemort: haha
BE11:23am

Neither of whom seem to have managed to deliver their spring-summer collections.

GBKrona @Mouselet - even if you are remote from your social circle, WhatsApp is the most popular long distance comms method, and now unfortunately is owned by Facebook
nichoman at least in the technological dystopia that our world has become we can still just turn off the computer or log out of facebook. when the machines take over, perhaps we will not even have that luxury and be forced to view facebook content all day...
Grouchmonkey I can't quite believe Moss Bross is still here. Why didn't it go the way of Dunn & Co (for those with long memories) and Austin Reed long ago?
Mouselet Isn't WhatsApp for one-to-one comms?
Otter Hello special friends that I like
A. M. @Mouselet: there are groups, I understand.
11:24 am
BE11:24am

You'll remember a few weeks ago we mentioned that Zara had cleared stuff to get the spring ranges in by mid January. Seems Moss is still to manage this two months later.

Fox Vectura must be an M&A candidate at these levels. GSK offered 175p/share according to Telegraph in Jan; now 75p. Assets include over £100M in cash.
Mouselet Hello special otter who is replete with merit. And, presumably, reasonably fresh fish, if he's been in the Thames recently
Grouchmonkey @mouselet indeed not. The WhatsApp group is a key social tool.
rw42 I'm still surprised that even if they can identify my political ideologies from fb they can then do anything useful with it - even if any targeted advert gets past the adblockers then it still needs to persuade me to do something i wasn't already going to do?
GBKrona @Mouselet - many people use it for closed group comms - even political parties
Bonnemort @mouse - you can have group chats, it's how our family keep in touch over 3 continents
BE11:25am

So, downgrades are massive.

BE11:25am

(@Fox: give it up, FFS.)

Mouselet I am not sure what the point is of small-group comms over just Facebook, but maybe I am an odd form of primate
Miss Piggy #Zuckerberg: what happens when a snowflake melts under pressure ... it becomes a drip.
Mouselet "Look at this baby it is cute" seems worth showing the universe rather than just the aunts
11:26 am
BE11:26am

You've also, as I say, got the hire business in terminal decline.

BE11:26am

Here's Peel Hunt's new numbers.

h1 @BE have a feeling its one of the next retailers to go bust
BE11:26am

The net effect is that we cut our PBT
expectations for FY2019 from £6.2m to £2.3m. Moss has signalled a reduction in the FY2018 dividend to 4.0p, with a view to the dividend being covered by 2021

Mouselet ( I suppose 'bloody hell the baby hasn't slept since January' might be more shown to the aunts than the universe )
Mouselet There is a bit of me that would very much rather laws to discourage uncovered dividends
Bonnemort Yes, when Primark can do a £50 tux and pants,, that one off hire is expensive.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

1.8p EPS versus 4p divi, you'll note.

Swedish Chef There must be a residual demand for suit hire. You may need to hire a suit for a forthcoming appearance before the Magistrates.
rw42 Last time i looked it was ~£50 to rent a tux and ~£150 to buy one that didn't look too awful. As it's lasted me through 4 christmas dos i figure i've made/saved money there..
FATDAZ @mouselett agreed re divis
Mouselet Because it's not a one-off hire of something obviously awesomely better than the Primark one, because you can't one-off-hire tailored garments because the library size would be absurd
Blue horseshoe... VEC look cheap
BE11:28am

Because Moss has spare cash and running it down with dividends is the most efficient way of getting rid, it seems.

Mouselet Hello people who talk only about Vectura, were you to stop I would not complain
BE11:28am

Meaning you have what looks like a dying business throwing off cash, which is straight weird but there we are.

Soundbuy @Swedish Chef - unless for a shoplifting charge whereby you may find one cheaper......
Miss Piggy Nearly-new Saville row suits £15 in Oxfam, (at least in Esher, Surrey).
Lemmy Wasn't that the Burton boss who said a lot of his customers were people getting a suit ahead of their first court appearance?
Mouselet meh, now I want to go to the far east again and get more garments
GBKrona @Mouselet - companies would then just use buybacks and capital returns - best to let shareholder governance deal with issues, rather than legislate, I feel
11:28 am
BE11:29am

Back to Peel Hunt, which goes "hold" from "buy".

Mouselet and expecting people to hear that as 'pupil barristers' rather than 'crooks' ?
BE11:29am

While the wedding season has yet to begin, the current order book suggests that the market is likely to remain challenging as trends continue to move against traditional hire product in favour of suit purchase. We have reduced our Hire sales (now -10%) and margin expectations for 2019E, such that our gross profit forecast is £1.5m below our previous
estimate. We estimate that the wedding hire business generates GP of c£5m

Jimmy Ms Piggy? Esher highsteet?
BE11:30am

Does Moss do kilts in Scotland, incidentally? I've hired a kilt. I can't for the life of me imagine hiring a suit.

Mouselet I thought Oxfam were nowadays better at distributing high-end used clothes rather than accumulating them
Mouselet IIRC a kilt is a £700 purchase and isn't very individually sized
Forester @lemmy cant mention the major name, but their CEO tolm me that in Liverpool they often have to refuse refunds on suits returned because they smell of embalming fluids etc!
Mouselet (but I am about as Scottish as octopus paella)
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Stores are profitable and the average time to end of lease/break clause is 37 months. The issue here has been largely down to stock availability rather than online disintermediation or consumer collapse and Moss retains a strong balance sheet.

Miss Piggy @Jimmy: Any Oxfam in a posh area is good tip.
Bonnemort I guess tails/morning suits might still be a hire decision
1 bid at 2 any further on FENR?
BE11:31am

(@Mouselet: this is accurate, and I'm as Scottish as deep fried octopus paella, as you know.)

undefined
Tom Dalgleish BE which clan r u?
hornblower I see Carpetright got a lifeline for now at least. £12m loan from shareholder v market cap £28m. going to do a £40-60m equity raise. hmmmm
Forester @bonnrmort Agree, thats about the only market. Youngsters dont hire DJs anymore
Lemmy Forester: haha. (and wonder if the initials were JH?)
Mouselet Mmm, deep fried octopus paella. Arancini, I guess
Miss Piggy @BE: was it tartan?, non-Scottish people are a bit stuck, it's possible to buy kilts in Harris tweed for those with no Caledonian ancestry.
pancakes or waffles I'm hungry now :(
11:32 am
BE11:32am

So .............. What else? Softcat mentioned earlier.

Mouselet https://www.mossbroshire.co.uk/occasion/highland £100 feels quite a lot
Fox RE: Fenner & Michelin - what happens to ex-Low&Bonar's CEO Brett Simpson now?
Forester @miss piggy a lot of lowland scots including my own family think tartan is just a load of victorian misty-eyed nonsense!
Tom Dalgleish Maybe its the Toady clan
Bonnemort Does it come with a claymore and targe?
BE11:33am

(@Miss Piggy: Roberts tartan, taking the family connection off my mother's side. It's relatively muted.)

Pseudonym It's a special fabric where blood and vomit can be easily washed out, not cheap stuff.
BE11:34am

There's nothing whatsoever wrong with Softcat's numbers.

Tom Dalgleish I'm McLaren from Grandmother tooooo
11:34 am
Softcat PLC (SCT:LSE): Last: 593.00, down 86 (-12.67%), High: 680.00, Low: 587.00, Volume: 855.04k
wayneJ Which MEP represented the UK on the fishing committee of the EU Parliament but failed to turn up to any meetings?
Mouselet Not, err, Dalgleish ?
LondonQuant Morning all
Mouselet wayneJ: I thought Farage turned up to one
Tom Dalgleish Not sure I should be conversing with a Roberts
BE11:35am

But the shares were inexplicably strong yesterday when everything else tech was was selling off.

Tom Dalgleish Mouse no there isnt one
BE11:35am

And "good enough" isn't really good enough when you're on 30x or thereabouts, in a sector where 15x is expensive.

Tom Dalgleish We feature in hangings but not the tartan registry
11:35 am
BE11:36am

Because it's just boring old IT infrastructure outsourcing, in the end.

wayneJ @Mouse - I stand corrected - once out of ???
BornCynic Those were the days - me hiring a kilt to impress a Scottish girl. All I did was make her homesick :)
GBKrona @wayneJ - the despicable Farage - but he only turned up to 1 meeting out of over 15
Tom Dalgleish Also drawing and quartering a family speciiality
BE11:36am

Credit Suisse saying take profit.

Swedish Chef The Clachaig Inn in Glencoe still has a sign “no Campbells” Any lawyers about?
BE11:36am

Softcat has delivered a very strong set of interims, as pre announced in the period end update. All metrics look good, with broad-based contributors to growth, strong cash flow and a strong outlook. onsequently, we upgrade FY18 and 19 EPS by 4-5%, taking us towards consensus that upgraded on the period-end update. We have no operational concerns, but we believe the share price now reflects this positive outlook. Softcat now has
broadly the same market cap as Computacenter and yet to Dec 18 we
forecast operating profit of £60m for Softcat and £105m for Computacenter.
We believe this highlights the future growth that is already reflected in the
Softcat valuation. On valuation grounds alone, we downgrade our rating from
Outperform to Neutral. Our target price increases to 700p (from 600p) with
the key risk to our target price being changes to partner terms/ relationships, but there is no sign of this happening.

Tom Dalgleish That's why I've never been one for reputations
Mouselet Were the entire artisanal British fishing industry converted to whale-watching and live-aboard diving, it would be of great merit to everyone
BillyRayValentine Micro Focus tanking once again...
11:37 am
BE11:37am

700p target, which is still 25 times YE2019 (allowing for the net cash).

BornCynic Mr Shiller writing in the Guardian:https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/mar/19/how-economies-could-insure-themselves-against-the-bad-times
Grouchmonkey @Swedish Campbells are a minority but are they an ETHNIC minority?Discuss.
Mouselet Only problem is the shortage of whales. Big government project to re-humpback the Wash clearly essential :)
#REF! wow ROTR further than usual from markets talk today :)
Soundbuy Didn't reckon on googling tartan images when I awoke this am,.....
wayneJ @GBK - indeed - it just beggars belief.
rw42 Bit chilly to get many people interested in diving too!
undefined
wayneJ On fishing - my understanding was that a decent % of our catch is exported to Europe - is that correct?
Miss Piggy I'd rather talk about Fed FOMC, until the Fed grey arrives, here is Harris Tweed Kilt at £850, http://21stcenturykilts.com/product/5/harris-tweed-kilt
Otter @Mouselet if the UK joined EFTA like the Norway they could hunt all the whales for food and profit and it would be helpful because the hunted species is becoming very populous
Lemmy wayneJ: most of it is, yes
Pseudonym @Otter I'm sure hunting the welsh is frowned on.
BE11:40am

Have to say, I'm quite enjoying Kilt Chat on the right. It's an unexpected new direction to take live markets coverage.

Swedish Chef I need a long term home for a legacy but in the meantime but happy to gossip about kilts too.
Soundbuy @wayneJ - yep, though we're pretty fussy as a nation when it comes to fish (without batter or a can)
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Anyone want to construct a basket of companies with their own registered tartans?

#REF! Alphaville ROTR - Skirting around market topics since...
BE11:41am

(The concept of "registered tartan" is complete hokum but let's ignore that for the moment.)

Miss Piggy Collateralised Debt Obligation based on tartan, isn't that Burberry?
wayneJ Dumb question - w.r.t CA and FB. Is there any implication that any HFs might be using unethically obtained FB data?
BE11:42am

Icelandair has one. So does Irn Bru, as in AG Barr.

Swedish Chef Thought Burberry check was the Millwall tartan.
Mouselet 50% of fish caught in UK exported to EU (and 25% to non-EU); >50% of fish eaten in UK imported, 33% from EU
Miss Piggy @Mouselet: higher.
Soundbuy Long kilts?
11:42 am
BE11:42am

And ....... uh, I think Rangers? Though that isn't the most liquid of investments any more.

BE11:43am

Have a look at the register yourself: https://www.tartanregister.gov.uk ... we need to keep within at least orbiting distance of the stock market theme.

undefined
wayneJ Just thinking also is it passive data analysis by quant HFs - or could they be actually paying for ads to actually tilt sales towards or away from a company? Eg lets say I was short Toys R Us (as an example ) - would it pay me to spend on ads for an alternative toy retailer in the endeavour to ensure that Toys R Us missed its numbers? (Yes I know Toys has gone bust but that is why I am using it as an example)
11:43 am
BE11:44am

Ocado!

Forester In these puritanical days, kilt wearing is inherently risk when combined with booze. Stopped wearing mine due to too many "incidents"!
BE11:44am

Goldman!

BE11:44am

Downgrade!

Mouselet we like eating prawns and cod and we are good at catching mackerel and export masses of lobsters and scallops
Mouselet (also Scottish smoked salmon, how could I forget scottish smoked salmon?)
11:44 am
BE11:44am

I spent too long this morning trying to work out if it's the first time Goldman's ever downgraded Ocado .....

Grouchmonkey SSE is vaguely Scottish. any news on the SSE - Innogy tie-up?
wayneJ @Mouselet - those numbers frankly scary - bit like counties demanding EU money after voting for Brexit.
BE11:44am

.... and, no. They took it off the buy list in 2011, for a month.

J L Hello, Joining late today.RIP Gulfsands
Mouselet Did the whole Google-vs-Interflora mess mean that companies at least checked that X wasn't buying adverts for Y
Mouselet (I am still amused at Amazon's automatic passing-off machine )
Otter I think there are also a lot of seals in the uk and they are easy to shoot and nutritious and could likely be exported to global hipsters even if they also have to pay a tarriff.
wayneJ @Mouselet - that is an interesting point - could an unscrupulous HF squeeze up the price of adwords for a co they are short?
BE11:45am

Ocado, for those joining us very late, was of course founded by three Goldman bankers and had Goldman as joint sponsor of the 2010 IPO, which went pear shaped.

Mouselet 'people who searched for Lush on Amazon bought this non-Lush bathbomb' => 'automatically buy Google Ads for the keyword Lush and link it to that non-Lush product'
Flaneur Otter.... you need help ;)
Mouselet which is an automatic passing-off machine
cracklenpop Mothercare's lenders showing forbearance
wayneJ @Mouselet - would be a form of 'activist quant investing'
Mouselet I can't think of a seal-eating culture, though there are always Icelanders
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Today's development is that Rob Joyce, the current GS Ocado analyst, is getting edgy about valuation.

Mouselet dog-meat that tastes of oily fish. Who could ask for that?
Mouselet I did eat whale once. It tasted of nice fillet steak which someone had unaccountably marinated in the oil from a tuna tin.
Bonnemort Inuit - and Antarctic explorers of old
BE11:47am

We update our numbers for Ocado post its 1Q trading update, and downgrade the stock to Neutral following its material outperformance. Results were in line with our expectations and we make immaterial changes to our
stimates with this note. Ocado’s share price has risen c.135% since announcing its agreements with Casino in November 2017 and Sobeys in January 2018, to provide those grocers with its end-to-end grocery solution, Ocado Smart Platform. While we believe there is a material opportunity for Ocado in the online grocery space, our target price already includes seven further OSP deals to be signed over the next 10 years of a similar size to those two. Thus, over the next 12 months, we see material upside only through the announcement of an agreement with a major grocer that could demand far more OSP capacity than we forecast, or a takeover bid – neither of which we have visibility on.

Soundbuy Microfocus off 7% - but that's not news....
wayneJ @BE - the Tartan Register has two tartans with the word finance or financial in the title but no Financial Times tartan - surely u will look to rectify that?
Mouselet Inuit, of course. Sorry.
Kiwi-juice IMB share price below 24 quid. 12% FCF Yield. Amazing markets
Mouselet A pale-salmon, pink and black tartan would be awful even by tartan standards
Bonnemort Seal brains au gratin recipe in Wally Herbert's book on Antarctic.
BE11:49am

(@Mouselet: was it AA Gill who described eating seal fin as like eating a Marigold glove filled with wallpaper paste? It's stuck in my memory but Google's not helpful.)

11:49 am
undefined

LJ @Forester- long term issues with changing regulation not putting you off? fantastic yield and long term holder anyway

LFL sharply negative at B&Q, unexpectedly, which also takes a margin hit due to clearance sales. Weak demand for big ticket, etc.

Tom Dalgleish Thats a red flag for Bunnings which is thinking closing shoppe
Grouchmonkey @kiwi fair point. Even if you think smoking is yesterday's habit net assets of 6,2bn must be worth something, surely?
Bonnemort No young house buyers = no big ticket DIY

No apparent uplift from Bunnings' disastrous relaunch, so the impression is that it's market wide.

1 bid at 2 Soph...ping,,
wayneJ I would humbly suggest a FT AV competition to design an appropriate tartan?

BE11:53am

But, of course, the Kingfisher investment story is that we're in year 37 of the five-year turnaround plan.

Blank canvas Smurfit under £30. The ice beginning to crack?
11:53 am

And that's going okay, apparently. Management confident of getting the full £500m.

BE11:54am

BE11:55am

The Kingfisher investment thesis hinges on the potential for earnings to step up materially over the coming three years. In this respect, its January 2018 performance (retail profits of £849m, broadly in line with our own expectations) is less relevant. The
group has contended with difficult end-market conditions and the acceleration of ONE Kingfisher over the past 12 months, keeping profits broadly flat on a year-on-year (yoy) basis. In fact, ONE Kingfisher progress is notable. However, a more difficult UK environment is now clearly impacting on B&Q, while cash has also
disappointed. We continue to believe that expectations around the programme, its balance sheet capacity and the stock in general remain muted. We reiterate our ‘Outperform’ recommendation.

BE11:55am

We are cutting 18/19 PBT forecasts by £20m to £861m to reflect a tougher
outlook in the UK, especially for big ticket (B&Q LFL -2%), but are well above consensus of £822m. We are trimming our 12m FWD target price in line to 410p (vs 425p). The company remains confident in delivering the full £500m benefit from “ONE Kingfisher”, digital is nearing completion, and the £100m of opex looks conservative, but the key will be delivery of gross margin and LFL uplifts in the year ahead. On 11.3x 12m FWD PER with 3.4% yield we
believe this discounts little benefit from the plan or the potential for Homebase/Wesfarmers to pull out of the UK (giving c10% potential uplift).

BE12:06pm

Management’s efforts over the past five years to consolidate, simplify and invest in the company’s brand portfolio have stemmed market share losses, but were not enough to compensate for the deteriorating trends across its key cigarette markets. While we recognise that on February 7, management reiterated its expectation for a 2H-weighted performance, we believe recent market weakness raises the risk of a miss to FY18 guidance of 1%-4% organic growth and EPS growth at the lower end of the 4%-8% range. The net effect of our revised organic revenue growth and operating margin expectations drives our adjusted EPS forecasts 3.1%/7.6%/12.1% lower in FY18-20. Compared with Reuters consensus, our EPS forecasts are now in line for FY18 and c.3% below for FY19/20.

The big risk for Imperial could lie in the tobacco pricing model unravelling. If IQOS as a concept starts to gain traction, with consumers gaining the belief it is much less bad for them, Imperial may not be in a position to take its ‘usual’ quantum of combustible pricing (or if it did, volume issues would be
ompounded). In this event, 15 to 25% profit cuts could ensue.
